form.current-chamber: IN THE SENATE OF THE UNITED STATES

action.action-desc: Mr. Lee (for himself, Ms. Klobuchar, Mr. Cruz, Mr. Blumenthal, Mr. Rubio, Ms. Warren, Mr. Schmitt, Mr. Hawley, Mr. Kennedy, Mr. Graham, and Mr. Vance) introduced the following bill; which was read twice and referred to the Committee on the Judiciary

form.official-title: To amend the Clayton Act to prevent conflicts of interest and promote competition in the sale and purchase of digital advertising.

section.text: This Act may be cited as the Advertising Middlemen Endangering Rigorous Internet Competition Accountability Act or the AMERICA Act.

section.header: Digital advertising trading transparency and competition
section.text: The Clayton Act (15 U.S.C. 12 et seq.) is amended by inserting after section 8 (15 U.S.C. 19) the following:

section.header: Competition and transparency in digital advertising

paragraph.text: The term brokerage customer means a person who has purchased or sold digital advertisements, or directly related goods or services, through a buy-side brokerage or a sell-side brokerage.

The term buy-side brokerage means a person in the business of effecting transactions on digital advertising exchanges, including by offering software or services that assist in serving or displaying digital advertisements, for other buyers.
The term digital advertisement means an advertisement that is served electronically over a computer network, including the internet.

The term digital advertising exchange means a person who constitutes, maintains, or provides a marketplace for or facilitates bringing together buyers and 1 or more third-party sellers of digital advertisements, or for otherwise performing with respect to digital advertising the functions commonly performed by a digital advertising marketplace.
The term digital advertising revenue means the greater of—

subparagraph.text: global revenue derived from or directly related to the operation of a digital advertising exchange, a buy-side brokerage, or a sell-side brokerage;
the sum of the clearing prices of all digital advertisements bought or sold from or through a digital advertising exchange;
the total value of the gross advertising spending managed by a buy-side brokerage; or
the total value of the gross advertising sales managed by a sell-side brokerage.

paragraph.text: The term divestiture deadline means the later of—

subparagraph.text: 30 days after the date on which the Attorney General approves or denies a required divestiture; or
30 days after the expiration of any applicable waiting period specified in section 7A.

paragraph.text: The term effective date means the date that is 1 year after the date of enactment of this section.
The term own means to own, operate, or control, directly or indirectly, in whole or in part.
The term person includes—

subparagraph.text: any subsidiary of an entity; and
any corporate parent of an entity.

paragraph.text: The term required divestiture—

subparagraph.text: means a divestiture, sale, or other transaction undertaken to comply with any provision of this Act; and
does not include any action required by a court of the United States.

paragraph.text: The term sell-side brokerage means a person in the business of effecting transactions on digital advertising exchanges, including by offering software or services that assist in serving or displaying digital advertisements, for third-party sellers.
The term third-party means, for each person subject to this Act, an entity that—

subparagraph.text: neither owns nor is owned by the person; and
is not affiliated with the person through direct or indirect ownership or control.

subsection.text: No person with more than $20,000,000,000 (as adjusted each year on January 1 by an amount equal to the percentage increase, if any, in the Consumer Price Index, as determined by the Department of Labor or its successor) in digital advertising revenue during the previous calendar year may, after the effective date—

paragraph.text: own a digital advertising exchange if the person—

subparagraph.text: owns a sell-side brokerage or a buy-side brokerage; or
is a seller of digital advertising space;

paragraph.text: own a sell-side brokerage if the person owns a buy-side brokerage; or
own a buy-side brokerage or a sell-side brokerage if the person is a buyer or seller of digital advertising space.

subsection.text: On and after the effective date, any person with more than $5,000,000,000 (as adjusted each year on January 1 by an amount equal to the percentage increase, if any, in the Consumer Price Index, as determined by the Department of Labor or its successor) in digital advertising revenue during the previous calendar year shall be subject to the following requirements:

paragraph.text: A buy-side brokerage or sell-side brokerage—

subparagraph.text: shall, in the course of providing services as a brokerage, use reasonable diligence, care, and skill to act in the best interests of the brokerage customers; and
may not put the interests of the brokerage ahead of those of the brokerage customers.

paragraph.text: A buy-side brokerage or sell-side brokerage shall seek the most favorable terms reasonably available under the circumstances for each order transaction of the brokerage customer.

subparagraph.text: Upon written request from a brokerage customer, a buy-side brokerage or sell-side brokerage shall supply to the brokerage customer, within a reasonable time, information sufficient to permit the brokerage customer to verify compliance of the brokerage with the obligations under paragraphs (1) and (2).
The information described in subparagraph (A) shall include, if requested and to the extent such information is collected by the brokerage in the ordinary course of business—

clause.text: in the case of a sell-side brokerage providing information to a sell-side brokerage customer—

subclause.text: a unique and persistent identifier that identifies each unique digital advertising space for sale;

for each identifier described in subclause (I), all bids received, and, for each bid received, the bid submitted to the digital advertising exchange on behalf of the buy-side brokerage customer, the winning price, the uniform resource locator or other property identifier at the lowest level of granularity, the identity of the digital advertising exchange or other digital advertising venue returning the bid, date, time that the bid response was received in microseconds or a lower level of granularity, web domain associated with the advertising creative, the advertising creative size and format, and whether the bid won the impression of the seller;
the nature of any data collected or derived from the brokerage customer or any user or customer of the brokerage customer, and the ways in which the data is used by the sell-side brokerage;
the order or bid routing practices or processes, including any material exceptions to the standard practice of the brokerage; and
the source and nature of any compensation paid or received in connection with transactions; and

clause.text: in the case of a buy-side brokerage providing information to a buy-side brokerage customer—

subclause.text: all bids won by the buy-side brokerage customer, and for each bid won, the maximum allowed bid of the advertiser, if any, the uniform resource locator or other property identifier at the lowest level of granularity, date, the digital advertising exchange, the web domain associated with the advertising creative, the advertising creative size and format, the winning price, the bid submitted to the digital advertising exchange on behalf of the buy-side brokerage customer, and, if possible, whether the ad served and whether the ad rendered;
the order or bid routing practices or processes; and
the source and nature of any compensation paid or received in connection with transactions.

subparagraph.text: Brokerages shall retain the applicable records specified in subparagraph (B) collected in the ordinary course of business until provided to a requesting brokerage customer but not longer than 90 days. Brokerages shall retain billing information for brokerage customers for not fewer than 12 months.

clause.text: When providing information to a brokerage customer in response to a request authorized by subparagraph (A), the brokerage shall, to the greatest extent possible consistent with the purpose of subparagraph (A), anonymize, hash, or otherwise render the information incapable of being tied to an individual web user.
A brokerage customer may not use data or information received in response to a request made under subparagraph (A) for any purpose other than—

subclause.text: verifying compliance of a brokerage with the obligations under paragraphs (1) and (2); or

subparagraph.text: Buy-side brokerages and sell-side brokerages shall establish, maintain, and enforce written policies and procedures reasonably designed to ensure compliance with the obligations under this subsection.

Persons not subject to prohibitions under subsection (b) shall establish, maintain, and enforce written policies and procedures reasonably designed to ensure that the buy-side brokerage, sell-side brokerage, digital advertising exchange, and role as a buyer or seller of digital advertising, as applicable, operate separate and independent from one another and transact business at arm’s length.

paragraph.text: A digital advertising exchange shall provide every buyer and seller in the exchange fair access, including with respect to operations of the exchange, colocation, any technology systems or data, information related to transactions, service, or products offered, exchange processes, and functionality.
A digital advertising exchange, buy-side brokerage, or sell-side brokerage shall—

subparagraph.text: synchronize its business clocks at a minimum to within a 2 milliseconds tolerance of the time maintained by the atomic clock of the National Institute of Standards and Technology; and
maintain the synchronization described in subparagraph (A).

paragraph.text: All records pertaining to an order solicited or submitted by a brokerage customer, and the subsequent result of the order, shall remain the property of the customer, including any bids solicited from or submitted to any digital advertising exchange, unless the information is otherwise publicly available.

subparagraph.text: Every sell-side brokerage and buy-side brokerage shall—

clause.text: make publicly available for each calendar quarter a report on the order routing practices of the sell-side brokerage or buy-side brokerage, as applicable, for digital advertisements during the quarter broken down by calendar month; and
retain the report described in clause (i) posted on an internet website that is free and readily accessible to the public for the 3-year period beginning on the date on which the report is posted.

subparagraph.text: Reports made available pursuant to subparagraph (A) shall—

clause.text: be rendered in a format that makes the reports readily informative to the average brokerage customer; and

include for the 10 venues to which the largest number of total bid requests or bid responses were routed for execution and for any venue to which 5 percent or more of bid requests or bid responses were routed for execution—

subclause.text: the total number of bids routed;
the total number of bids executed;
the average net execution fee or rebate per 1,000 impressions;
the average time in milliseconds between when a bid request is sent and when a bid response is received; and
the value and form of any compensation given in exchange for routing or execution.

paragraph.text: A digital advertising exchange, buy-side brokerage, or sell-side brokerage shall certify to the Attorney General on an annual basis that the digital advertising exchange has complied with the requirements under this subsection.

paragraph.header: Attorney general and state attorneys general

subparagraph.text: In this paragraph, the term Fund means the Antitrust Consumer Damages Fund established under subparagraph (D).

The Attorney General and State attorneys general may bring an action on behalf of persons in the United States injured in their business or property by reason of any violation of this section in any district court of the United States in the district in which the defendant resides or is found or has an agent, without respect to the amount in controversy, and shall—

clause.text: in a case brought by the Attorney General or a State attorney general, be entitled to injunctive relief; and
in a case brought by the Attorney General, recover damages sustained by such persons.
The court may award under this subsection, pursuant to a motion by the Attorney General promptly made, simple interest on actual damages in accordance with subparagraph (B).

A court may not award any damages under this subparagraph that are duplicative of damages awarded before the date of the award under this subparagraph in a separate civil action pertaining to the same conduct and injured party.

A court awarding damages to a person in a civil action after the date of an award of damages under this subsection that would be duplicative of damages awarded to the Attorney General on behalf of the person shall direct that such damages shall first be paid by the Attorney General from amounts in the Fund and, to the extent such damages are not fully paid from amounts in the Fund, shall be paid by the defendant.
There is established in the Treasury of the United States a fund to be known as the Antitrust Consumer Damages Fund, which shall consist of amounts deposited under clause (ii).
Notwithstanding section 3302 of title 31, United States Code, any amounts received by the Attorney General under an award under this subsection—

subclause.text: shall be deposited in the Fund; and

shall be available to the Attorney General, without further appropriation, for distribution to persons in the United States harmed by the applicable violation of the Sherman Act (15 U.S.C. 1 et seq.).

clause.text: Effective on the day after the date that is 10 years after the date on which an award is received under this paragraph, the unobligated balances in the Fund of amounts that were received under the award are rescinded and shall be deposited in the general fund of the Treasury.

paragraph.text: The Attorney General may bring an action on behalf of the United States in any district court of the United States in the district in which the defendant resides or is found or has an agent, and may obtain injunctive relief upon showing by a preponderance of the evidence that the defendant has—

subparagraph.text: violated a requirement of subsection (e); or
undertaken a required divestiture that unnecessarily harms or threatens competition in any market.

A brokerage customer harmed by a knowing violation of subsection (c) by a person with more than $20,000,000,000 (as adjusted each year on January 1 by an amount equal to the percentage increase, if any, in the Consumer Price Index, as determined by the Department of Labor or its successor) in digital advertising revenue during the previous calendar year may bring a civil action in an appropriate court to obtain injunctive relief, if appropriate, and recover damages in the amount of the greater of—

clause.text: $1,000,000 for each month in which the violation occurred and reasonable attorney’s fees; or
actual damages and reasonable attorney’s fees.

subparagraph.text: No person covered by this section may require a class action waiver for claims under this section, including for arbitration.
A civil action for a violation of subsection (b) may be brought at any time after the later of—

clause.text: the expiration of any applicable divestiture deadline; or
the expiration of the deadline described in subsection (e)(1) if no filing has been made.

paragraph.text: Any agreement or other document setting out the terms of a required divestiture shall be filed with the Attorney General not later than the later of—

subparagraph.text: the effective date; or
the earlier of—

clause.text: 30 days after the date on which an agreement making a required divestiture under this Act is executed; or
180 days after meeting the criteria specified in any paragraph of subsection (b).

paragraph.text: The Attorney General shall approve a required divestiture upon a showing by the person making the divestiture that the terms of the divestiture, including the qualifications of any counterparty to the divestiture, will not unnecessarily harm or threaten competition in any market.

subparagraph.text: The Attorney General shall grant or deny approval of a required divestiture, unless agreed to by the parties, not later than the later of—

clause.text: 60 days after receipt of all information obtained pursuant to subparagraph (5); or
60 days after receipt of the filing made under subparagraph (1).

subparagraph.text: A divestiture shall be completed not later than the divestiture deadline.

paragraph.text: The Attorney General shall—

subparagraph.text: not later than 120 days after the date of enactment of this section, issue guidance on the divestiture process under this subsection and the certification requirement under subsection (c)(9); and
update the guidance described in subparagraph (A) as the Attorney General determines is appropriate.

paragraph.text: The Attorney General may request or issue a civil investigative demand under section 3 of the Antitrust Civil Process Act (15 U.S.C. 1312) for documents from any person involved in a required divestiture to determine the competitive effects of the divestiture.
prohibit a person from—

subparagraph.text: selling their own inventory of advertising space if—

clause.text: the inventory was not acquired solely for the purposes of resale, except to monetize the content or intellectual property of the person; and
the person does not also assist a third party in the sale or purchase of advertising space, other than purchasing advertising space from the person; or

subparagraph.text: buying inventory to market the products or services of the person;

paragraph.text: abridge or supersede any provision of, or rules issued pursuant to, section 7A;
prohibit a person from, consistent with the antitrust laws, entering into a joint venture or other collaboration to prevent harm from spam, fraud, or other forms of abuse in digital advertising; or
require the disclosure of information if the disclosure would violate a law of the United States or a foreign country.
